HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase more pigs to raise

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 45 year-old Rose M.. She is married and has six children, aged between 10 and 23. In 2004, Rose established her crops business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $90 every month from this business. Rose has already received, and successfully repaid, two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more crops in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately US $17. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy more crops in bulk.

loans.name: Gulyaz

texts.en: Gulyaz was born in 1973. She is a mother of 2 children. This woman is an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, the Djabrayil region, and she settled in the Khirdalan settlement. She has run this business for 3 years. Now she needs a loan of $625 to buy foodstuffs to improve her business.

loans.use: Buy foodstuffs

loans.name: Linda

texts.en:
Linda, 42 years old, is single and lives in a small village in the South of Lebanon. Linda is a dress designer. She needs a loan of US$500 to purchase a new sewing machine in order to expand her business, which she has named Al Rabih (Arabic: Spring).

Linda has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua for three cycles and always repays her loans on time.

loans.use: Purchase a new sewing machine

loans.name: Loch

texts.en:
Loch L. grows crops on her farmland behind her house, which she sells in the local market. Her husband is a bricklayer. Mrs. L. earns $2 per day and her husband earns $4 per day. They live with one child in Tapang Village, Siem Reap Province, Cambodia.

Mrs. L. is asking for a loan to purchase fertilizer because it will allow her to increase the yield of her crops, allowing her to grow and sell more, thereby increasing her family’s income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase fertilizer for her crops

loans.name: Richard

texts.fr:
Richard Z. is 35 years old, is married and a father of 4 children. He is a textile artisan from Assahoun, a village located approximately 50 kilometers from Lome, the Togolese capital. He has carried on this activity for the past 5 years and the fruits of his work help him to provide for the needs of his family. With this loan, his second from FECECAV, Richard would like to buy strings for his textile work, and to arrange his workshop. This will enable him build his clientele and earn more money to provide for the needs of his family.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Richard Z. est âgé de 35 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants. Il est tisserand à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Il exerce cette activité depuis 5 ans et les fruits de son travail lui permettent de subvenir aux besoins de sa famille. Richard souhaite par ce crédit, le deuxième de FECECAV, acheter des ficelles lui permettant d’exécuter son travail, et aménager son atelier. Ceci lui permettra de conquérir beaucoup de clients et de gagner plus d’argent pour subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: To buy strings for his workshop

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Imelda

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 33 year-old Imelda M.. She is married, and has four children aged between 9 and 16. In 2006, Imelda established her grocery business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $140 every month from this business. Imelda requires a loan in order to buy more beer and soft drinks. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately US $48. She thanks you for your support.

Her bar is a good place to chill with a beer if you manage to finish work early on a Friday afternoon. It’s the kind of place where you kick back on a plastic chair under a tree, with a local beer in hand, the aroma of roasting ‘mishikaki’ (kebabs made on an open fire) wafting around you, and talk to anyone and everyone who happens to wander by.

loans.use: To buy more beer and soft drinks.

loans.name: Hong

texts.en:
Hong S. grows crops on her farmland, which is located behind her house. Mrs. S. makes a living by selling these crops at the local market, where she earns approximately $4 per day from her farming activities. She and her husband, Uch Chung, live with one child in Thnal Trang Village, Siem Reap Province, Cambodia. Mr. Chung is a motorcycle taxi driver. His motorcycle is old and does not attract many customers, so Mrs. S. is requesting a loan to purchase a newer motorcycle for him. The new motorcycle will allow him to serve more customers and thereby increase their family income.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help them achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To purchase a newer motorcycle for motorcycle taxi business

loans.name: Victor

texts.fr:
Victor A. is 53 years old, is married and a father of 5 children who all attend school. Since his childhood, he has been living in Assahoun, a village located approximately 50 kilometers from Lome, the Togolese capital. This is his second credit, and with it, he would like to buy a mill. The mill will help him meet the needs of his business. The profits he gains will make it possible for Mr. Victor to help his family's needs.

Translated from French by Ivana Kostic, Kiva Volunteer.

Victor A. est âgé de 53 ans, marié et père de 5 enfants tous à l’école. Il habite depuis son enfance à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Il souhaite par ce second crédit acquérir un moulin pour son exploitation. Ce qui lui permettra de répondre à un besoin du milieu. Les gains issus de son activité permettront à monsieur Victor de faire face aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: Acquire a mill

loans.name: Doeurn

texts.en:
Doeurn E., pictured in the photo, is a farmer, and her husband, Him Kheng, is an ox trader. They live in Boeng Chum Village in SiE. Reap Province, Cambodia. They have six children, two of whom are married. One of their sons is a bricklayer who contributes his wages towards the family’s expenses. Mr. Kheng needs additional working capital for his ox trading business because the business is expanding. Mrs. E. is requesting the loan for her husband so that they will have enough capital to grow the ox trading business.

About Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL): Hattha Kaksekar Limited (HKL) is one of Cambodia's largest and most successful microfinance institutions (MFIs). It is committed to helping its clients achieve their business goals by providing sound financial services, and thereby hopes to contribute to the social and economic development of Cambodia. HKL specifically targets women and poor families in order to help thE. achieve increased financial security and quality of life, by offering various credit programs and encouraging savings. In accordance with its mission and its commitment to operational and financial sustainability, HKL contributes part of its net profits every year to support social development in education and healthcare.

loans.use: To grow their ox trading business

loans.name: Helen

texts.en:
Helen, 37 years old, is single and lives in a village close to Nabatieh in the South of Lebanon. Helen is very hardworking and determined to make a difference in her family life. She bakes delicious flat bread on a "Saj," the bakery equipment you can see on the picture. She named her business Al Jawhar (Arabic: The Jewel) and needs a loan of US$300 to purchase ingredients and fuel.

This is the first time Helen has requested a loan from Al Majmoua. She promises to repay her loan on time and thereby prove her seriousness.

loans.use: To purchase the ingredients and fuel for breadmaking

loans.name: Mabontu Group

texts.en:
Ibrahim B. is happy with the SMT program and especially with Kiva. With his previous loans, Ibrahim's capital increased and now he is able to purchase most of his stock from the Republic of Guinea, where he can buy goods for cheaper and make a better profit. The 35-year-old sells cosmetics and has been doing business for five years; he has said that his business has expanded as a result of the loans from SMT.

Ibrahim is the leader of "Mabontu," a group of entrepreneurs working together for more than two years. Also in the group are: Mabinty T., who owns a small kiosk, and Tugiatu K., who sells utensils and dishes in Magburaka town, Sierre Leone. Together they are applying for a group loan to expand their individual businesses.

loans.use: To purchase stock of cosmetics and dishes.

loans.name: Ruth

texts.fr:
Ruth Z. is 39 years old, married, and the mother of four children. For years, she has been a hairdresser and retailer of hair extensions to her clientele in Assahoun, a village about 50 kilometers from the Togolese capital of Lomé. With this, her third loan, Ruth hopes to buy more beauty products and hair extensions in order to expand her business and thereby provide for her family.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Ruth Z. est âgée de 39 ans, mariée et mère de 4 enfants. Elle coiffeuse et revendeuse de mèches destinées à ses propres clientes depuis des années à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Avec ce troisième crédit, madame Ruth désire acheter plus de produits de beauté et de mèches pour augmenter la capacité de son activité et par là subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: Purchase of beauty products and hair extensions to expand business

loans.name: Rima

texts.en:
Rima, 47 years old, is single and lives in a small village in the South of Lebanon. Her goal is to have a regular revenue stream and to provide for the basic needs of her family. Rima produces home-made mouneh (Arabic: food that is stored for later consumption, such as pickles, jams, tomato paste, etc.) She named her business Al Khayr (Arabic: good fortune).

Rima needs a loan of US$500 to purchase more ingredients and thereby expand her business. Rima has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua for two cycles and has repaid her loans on time.

loans.use: Purchase of raw material to ensure food items production

loans.name: Zakir

texts.en: Zakir was born in 1974. He is  an Internally Displaced Person (IDP) from the Armenian-occupied territory of Azerbaijan, Khodjali town, and he settled in Baku city.  He has run this business of building houses for 4 years.  Now he needs a loan of $625 to buy necessary materials for building houses.

loans.use: to buy necessary materials for building the houses

loans.name: Sobhiyeh

texts.en: Sobhiyeh is 54 years old and lives in a small village in the South of Lebanon. Sobhiyeh owns a grocery store that she named Al Saadeh (Arabic: Happiness). She needs a loan of US$ 200 to enlarge and diversify the inventory of goods she can offer to her clients. This is the first time Sobhiyeh has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Purchase of inventory for her grocery shop

loans.name: Régine

texts.fr:
Régine E. is 34 years old. She is married and has one child. For three years, she has sold sacks of coal, both wholesale and retail, in Assahoun, a village about 50 kilometers from the Togolese capital of Lomé. With this loan, she hopes to buy new sacks of coal in order to increase the scope of her business and to meet the needs of her clients. The profits she earns by her occupation will allow her to help meet the needs of her household. In the photo, Régine is the person on the left. Her younger sister helps her.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning, Kiva Volunteer.

Régine E. est âgée de 34 ans, mariée et mère d’un enfant. Elle achète et revend depuis 3 ans en gros et en détail des sacs de charbon à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle souhaite par ce crédit acheter de nouveaux sacs de charbon, afin d’augmenter la capacité de son commerce et faire face aux besoins de sa clientèle. Les profits tirés de son activité lui permettront de prendre en charge une partie des besoins de son foyer. dans la photo,Régine est la personne située à gauche. Elle est aidée par sa petite soeur.

loans.use: Purchase of new sacks of coal

loans.name: Bushra's Group

texts.en:
Bushra baji is the wife of Z. I., and she lives in the city of Chichawatni in Pakistan. She has been married for one year, and her husband is a fruit seller. In practice, her husband sells fruit on a cart. Meanwhile, Bushra baji is a housewife, though she also makes embroidered clothes. She is hereby applying for a loan in order to buy more fruit for her husband’s fruit business.

She is joined in her loan group by the following individuals: (1) Hamidan baji, who seeks a loan to buy a motorbike for her motorbike rental business; (2) Shazia baji, who requests a loan to buy fruit to sell; (3) Maqbool baji, who asks for a loan for her tie-dye business (she dyes ladies’ scarves); and (4) Farzana baji, who wants a loan to buy wheat to resell.

This is a group loan. As such, the loan proceeds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Further, the members mutually guarantee each other's loans; therefore, if one member does not repay her loan, the other members are responsible for the arrears.

loans.use: To improve and expand their respective businesses (e.g., to purchase additional fruit, wheat, a motorbike, and materials for a tie-dye business)

loans.name: Sina

texts.en: Sina, 41 years old, lives in a small village close to Nabatieh in the South of Lebanon. Sina bakes flat bread on a Saj, the equipment you can see in the picture. As she currently rents the baking equipment, she needs a loan of US$300 to purchase a machine for blending the dough and Saj baking equipment. This will allow her to expand her business and increase her income. This is the first time Sina has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Purchase a dough blender and baking equipment.

loans.name: Zeb-Un-Nisa's Group

texts.en:
Zeb-un-Nisa baji is the wife of S. A., and she lives in the city of Chichawatni in Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, and she has lived in this house for the last 24 years. She is the mother of seven children: five sons and two daughters. All of her sons completed their studies through 10th standard (grade), but they were unable to receive higher education (despite the fact that they wanted to) due to their poor financial situations. She is a housewife, and she prefers to do house-related work. Her husband works in a bus station. She has already successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute), which was used to start her own cigarette business. Now, she is applying for a loan to buy more cigarettes to sell.

She is joined in her loan group by the following individuals: (1) Naseem baji, who seeks a loan to buy fruit to sell; (2) Shazia baji, who requests a loan to expand her embroidery business; and (3) Rashida baji, who asks for a loan to buy wheat to resell.

This is a group loan. As such, the loan proceeds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Further, the members mutually guarantee each other's loans; therefore, if one member does not repay her loan, the other members are responsible for the arrears.

loans.use: To improve and expand their respective businesses (e.g., by purchasing additional cigarettes, fruit, wheat, and materials for an embroidery business)

loans.name: Félicia

texts.fr:
Félicia E. is 38 years old. She is the married mother of five children, of which three are apprenticed and two are in school. For more than three years, she has run a shop in Assahoun, a village about 50 kilometers from the Togolese capital of Lomé. Félicia is a loyal client of FECECAV, this being her second loan; with it, she wishes to buy loincloths for resale in order to increase profits and provide for her family’s needs.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Félicia E. est âgé de 38 ans mariée et mère de 5 enfants dont 3 sont en apprentissage et 2 à l’école. Elle tient son petit commerce depuis plus de 3 ans à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Félicia est une cliente fidèle de FECECAV car elle est à son deuxième crédit et souhaite par ce dernier acheter plus de pagnes pour la revente afin de dégager plus de profits et subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: Purchase of loincloths for resale

loans.name: God Tenki Group

texts.en:
Abi K. is the leader for the group "God Tenki". The four members sell their goods in the same market and have been working cohesively as a rotating savings club for a long time. The group joined the SMT program when it was established in Magburaka, Sierre Leone, and are now applying for a loan together to expand their individual businesses.

Abi is 50 years old and married with four children. Her business supplements her husband's meager income as a teacher. She sells utensils and other dishes. Abi would like to build her capital and diversify her business.

Also in the group are: Kadiatu K., who sells peanuts butter and would like to purchase 15 bags of peanuts; Marie L., who sells firewood/fuel; and Saffie K., who sells palm oil.

loans.use: Increase stocks of utensils/dishes, wood/fuel, peanuts and palm oil

loans.name: Saima's Group

texts.en:
Saima baji is the wife of M., and she lives in the city of Chichawatni in Pakistan. She is the mother of one daughter. Her husband runs his own barber shop, and he has been in this profession for the last 15 years. She is a housewife, and she actually prefers to do such house-related work. She has already successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan), and she is now applying for a loan to buy materials for her husband’s barber shop.

She is joined in her loan group by the following individuals: (1) Asia baji, who seeks a loan for her cigarette business; (2) Shahnaz baji, who requests a loan to buy (and later resell) cotton; and (3) Nasreen baji, who asks for a loan in order to expand her catering business.

This is a group loan. As such, the loan proceeds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Further, the members mutually guarantee each other's loans; therefore, if one member does not repay her loan, the other members are responsible for the arrears.

loans.use: To improve and expand their respective businesses (e.g., by purchasing cigarettes, cotton, or materials for a catering business)

loans.name: Milad

texts.en: Milad, 35 years old, is single and lives in Tripoli,  North Lebanon. where he owns a snack shop. His enthusiasm and will power help his business grow every day. Milad has requested a loan of US$1,000 to increase and diversify his inventory so that he may offer a larger menu to his clients. Indeed, during the summer season, Milad's snack-cafe cannot satisfy the demand of all his clients. This is the first time that Milad has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: Purchase food products and diversify the snack inventory

loans.name: Véronique

texts.fr:
Véronique G. is 35 years old. She is married and the mother of two children.She owns a loincloth store in Assahoun, a village about 50 kilometers from the Togolese capital of Lomé. This is her first loan coordinated through FECECAV. With it, she hopes to increase the scope of her business by purchasing many more loincloths, as well as thread for sewing, to satisfy her customers’ needs and draw in much more profit. In so doing, she will contribute to the improvement of her family’s living conditions.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Véronique G. est âgée de 35 ans, mariée et mère de 2 enfants. Elle tient une boutique de pagnes à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Elle souhaite par ce premier crédit de FECECAV accroître la taille de son activité, en achetant beaucoup plus de pagnes et des fils à coudre, pour satisfaire la clientèle et dégager beaucoup plus de bénéfice. Ce faisant elle contribuera à l’amélioration des conditions de vie de a famille.

loans.use: Purchase of many more loincloths

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 25, 2008)

loans.name: Parveen's Group

texts.en:
Parveen baji is the wife of M., and she lives in the city of Chichawatni in Pakistan. She is the mother of one son who is 2 years old. Her husband is a driver; more specifically, her husband drives an auto-rickshaw, a local three-wheeled motor vehicle. She has already successfully repaid her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan), which had been used to enable her husband to start a fruit business. Now, she is applying for a loan so that her husband can buy an auto-rickshaw because the driving industry is more profitable than the fruit-selling business.

She is joined in her loan group by the following individuals: (1) Shagufta baji, who seeks a loan to expand her wood furniture business; and (2) Shabana baji and (3) Sughran baji, both of whom request a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw.

This is a group loan. As such, the loan proceeds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Further, the members mutually guarantee each other's loans; therefore, if one member does not repay her loan, the other members are responsible for the arrears.

loans.use: To improve and expand their respective businesses (e.g., by purchasing rickshaws or materials for a furniture business)

loans.name: Takolo Group

texts.en:
Adama T. is 38 years old and married with children; she has to work hard to supplement her husbands income in order to support the family. Adama's husband runs a small kiosk in the outskirts of Magburaka town, Sierre Leone, while Adama sells utensils in the town. With her previous loan from SMT, Adama is experiencing an increase in her stock and income.

Adama is the leader for a group of entrepreneurs. The solidarity of the group is very strong, and they guarantee each other for loans. Mabinty K. also sells dishes, while Isata J. and Fatmata K. sell palm oil. The members would like to increase their stock and income, and are therefore requesting a loan for this purpose.

loans.use: To purchase more utensils/dishes and palm oil to increase income

loans.name: Shamshad's Group

texts.en:
Shamshad baji is the wife of M., and she lives in the city known as Chichawatni in Pakistan. She owns a two-room brick house, and she has been living there for the last 16 years. She is the mother of six children: three daughters and three sons. Her husband sells wheat, and he has been in this profession for the last 4 years. Shamshad baji is a housewife, and she prefers to do house-related work. She is applying for a loan in order to buy more wheat for her husband’s business.

She is joined in her loan group by the following members: (1) Nasreen baji, who seeks a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (a local three-wheeled motor vehicle); (2) Naziran baji, who requests a loan to buy cotton and to resell such cotton; (3) Razia baji, who would like a loan to buy fruits to sell; and (4) Bushran baji, who asks for a loan to buy an auto-rickshaw.

This is a group loan. As such, the loan proceeds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. Further, the members mutually guarantee each other's loans; therefore, if one member does not repay her loan, the other members are responsible for the arrears.

loans.use: To improve and expand their respective businesses (e.g., to repair/purchase rickshaws, to purchase cotton and fruits, etc.)

loans.name: Edoh

texts.fr:
Edoh A. is forty years old. She is married and is the mother of three children. She lives in Assahoun, a village about 50 kilometers from the Togolese capital of Lomé. She has been a retailer of vegetable foodstuffs for more than five years. With her second loan, she hopes to increase her stocks of peanuts, corn, millet, beans, and other cereals, with a view to reselling them to expand her business. The profits from her occupation will allow her to better meet the needs of her family.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Edoh A. est âgée de 40 ans, mariée et mère de 3 enfants. Il habite à Assahoun, un village situé à environ 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. Madame est revendeuse de produits vivriers depuis plus de 5 ans. Avec ce second crédit, elle souhaite faire davantage de stocks d’arachides, de maïs, de mils, du haricot et autres céréales en vue de les revendre pour augmenter la capacité de son commerce. Les bénéfices de son activité lui permettront de mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: Purchase of corn, beans, millet, and peanuts for resale

loans.name: Kayan

texts.en: Kayan, 44 years old, is a mother of 4 children in Tripoli, North Lebanon. Kayan has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua for 15 lending cycles and has always repaid her loans on time. During this period, Kayan was an active member in a group composed of several women. From the loans she took, she opened a flower shop next to her home. She is now requesting an individual loan of US$1,200 to purchase flowers and arrangement accessories in order to expand her business.

loans.use: Purchase flowers and flowers arrangement accessories

loans.name: Tutindaga

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 38 year-old Tutindaga M.. She is married, and has three children aged 8,14 and 17. She has one dependent who lives with her because he is an orphan. In 2006, Tutindaga established her boutique business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $90 every month from this business. Tutindaga requires a loan in order to buy more boutiques. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately US $43. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more boutiques.

loans.name: Ahmad

texts.en:
Ahmad, 51 years old, lives with his wife and 2 children in Tripoli, Northern Lebanon. Ahmad owns a shop where he sells spare parts and accessories for cars. He is a very hardworking person and very determined to make a difference in his family life.

Ahmad has been working in this business for a long time. He needs a loan of US$1,200 to purchase more goods for his shop. He promises to repay his loan on a monthly basis. This is the first time Ahmad has requested a loan from A. Majmoua.

loans.use: To increase shop inventory

loans.name: Kodzo

texts.fr:
Kodzo A. is 38 years old. He is married and father to four children. He lives fifty kilometers from Lomé, the capital of Togo. He is a chaffeur and taxi driver who owns his own vehicle. With this loan, he wishes to replace his motor; it is worn out, and is the cause of frequent breakdowns that prevent him from working regularly. The replacement of the motor and the servicing of the car will allow him to spend less and save more, the better to provide for his family.

Translated from French by Jonah Durning-Hammond, Kiva Volunteer.

Kodzo A. est âgé de 38 ans, marié et père de 4 enfants. Il habite à 50 kilomètres de Lomé, la capitale togolaise. II est chauffeur, conducteur de taxi et propriétaire de son propre véhicule. Avec ce nouveau crédit, il désire renouveler le moteur qui est trop usé et source de fréquentes pannes ce qui l’empêche de travailler normalement. Le renouvellement du moteur et la révision de la voiture lui permettront de dépenser moins et d’économiser plus pour mieux subvenir aux besoins de sa famille.

loans.use: Replacement of motor and servicing of automobile

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for FECECAV - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Said

texts.en:
Said, 52 years old, is married with 3 children and lives in Tripoli, Northern Lebanon. Said works in the trade and maintenance of bicycles. The honesty, sincerity, and seriousness of Said in the domain of managing his business attracts clients to his shop, even from remote regions.

Said needs a loan of US$1,200 to expand his business by increasing inventory. This is the second time he has requested a loan from A. Majmoua. He also used his first loan to increase his business inventory and he repaid it on-time.

loans.use: Increase business inventory

loans.name: Ali

texts.en: Ali, 28 years old, is a married man and father of 1 child.  He lives in Northern Lebanon and owns a car washing facility. He started this business seven years ago. His will power and enthusiasm pushed him to request a loan from Al Majmoua for US$1,200 to enlarge his business activities. This is the first time that Said has requested a loan from Al Majmoua.

loans.use: To enlarge business activities

loans.name: Hafizan's Group

texts.en:
Hafizan baji, the widow of Muhammad B., lives in Chichawatni, Pakistan where she owns a mud house that has been her residence for the last 10 years. She is the mother of eight children: five sons and three daughters. Two daughters and two sons are married. Hafizan baji sells garments and does household work. Having successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan), she is now applying for a new one to buy more garments to expand her business.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Shamim baji wants a loan to buy utensils to sell; Sumera baji wants to buy a sewing machine for a tailoring business; Nasreen baji and Safia baji want loans to buy buffalo.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Yusta

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30 year-old Yusta K.. She is married and has four children, aged between 2 and 15. In 2000, Yusta established her small shop business. Working seven days a week, and five to eight hours a day, she earns about US $40 every month from this business. Yusta requires a loan in order to buy more goods in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately US $13. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. This leads to poor financial support hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement.

loans.use: To buy more goods in bulk.

loans.name: Pan Sellers Group

texts.en:
Kadiatu C. is 50 years old and married with three children. She sells dishes in the town of Magburaka, Sierra Leone, and the surrounding villages. With her previous loan from Kiva, Kadiatu increased her stock and diversified her outreach, extending her sales to the surrounding villages. Kadiatu is happy that with her increased income, she was able to meet one of her children's school requirements. She would now like to continue expanding her business.

Marie C. owns a local restaurant and would like to purchase bags of rice, gallons of palm oil and vegetables; Fatmata F. owns a food market and Mariam C. sells dishes. The group is requesting a loan to expand their businesses.

loans.use: To purchase inventory -- dishes and foodstuffs -- and increase income.

loans.name: Mahmoud

texts.en: Mahmoud, 43 years old, is married and the father of four children.  He lives close to the city of Tripoli in the North of Lebanon and owns a grocery store. Mahmoud has requested a loan of US$1,000 to purchase more goods and diversify his grocery inventory. This inventory increase will allow him to expand his business by attracting more clients. This is the first time that Mahmoud has requested a loan from A. Majmoua.

loans.use: Purchase goods inventory

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Al Majmoua Lebanese Association for Development, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 23, 2008)

loans.name: Ashraf

texts.en: Ashraf, 26 years old, was living with his wife and 1 child in the Palestinian camp of Naher Al Bared in the North of Lebanon. Unfortunately, he was obliged to leave his home after Al Bared war, and moved to another village where he rented a barber shop for men's haircuts. He needs  USD 1,000 to open his own shop and purchase new materials. Ashraf has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua for the past 3 years and has always repaid his debts on-time.

loans.use: Opening of a barber shop

loans.name: Khaled

texts.en: Khaled, 42 years old, is married with 3 children and lives in the North of Lebanon. Khaled owns a shop for gadgets and accessories.  He needs an amount of USD 1,200 to purchase more goods and diversify his inventory. He wants to expand his business in order to guarantee a better livelihood to his family. Khaled has been a micro-credit client of Al Majmoua for the past 5 years and always repaid his debts on time.

loans.use: Purchase of goods to diversify business inventory

loans.name: Yasmeen's Group

texts.en:
Yasmeen baji, the wife of I. A., lives in Chichawatni, Pakistan where she owns a three-room brick house. She is the mother of four daughters, all enrolled in a local school in her neighborhood. Yasmeen baji is a seamstress who has successfully completed her first loan from Asasah (a microfinance institute of Pakistan) and is now applying for a new one to buy a sewing machine to stitch more clothes.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Rashida baji wants a loan to buy a buffalo; Allah Rakhi baji wants to expand her milk business; Safia baji wishes to expand her food business; Razia baji wants a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Mesi

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 39 year-old Mesi S.. She is a widow and has one child, aged 15. In 2002, Mesi established her spears store business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $50 every month from this business. Mesi has already received, and successfully repaid, two loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more goods in bulk. She hopes that this loan will enable her to increase her monthly profits by approximately US $9. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. loans.use: To buy more goods in bulk.

loans.name: Majidan's Group

texts.en:
Majidan baji, the wife of J. M., has been living in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 13 years. She owns a two-room mud house and is the mother of two sons. Her husband has been in the business of selling sugarcane syrup for the last five years, and Majidan is applying for a loan on his behalf to buy more materials such as sugarcane and ice so he can expand his business and earn more profit.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Razia baji wants a loan to repair an auto-rickshaw (local three-wheeled motor vehicle); Bilquis baji wishes to buy a cart for selling cooked chickpeas and rice; Abida baji wants to expand her fruit business, while Mukhtar baji wants a loan to diversify her grocery shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

payments.comment: scheduled_repayment (late autopay posting for Asasah, a partner of Save the Children - Oct 24, 2008)

loans.name: Ester

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 38 year-old Ester P.. She is married and has four children, aged between 9 and 14. In 2007, Ester established her genge business. Ester requires a loan in order to buy more utensils. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy more utensils.

loans.name: Frola

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 30 year-old Frola S.. She is married and has two children, aged 1 and 6. She has two dependents, who live with her because they are orphans. In 2001, Frola established her genge business. Working seven days a week, and thirteen to sixteen hours a day, she earns about US $430 every month from this business. Frola requires a loan in order to buy more goods in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

The Swahili word for this type of outside shop, or stall, is genge. A genge is usually a very basic structure made of wood, with a tin roof, which sells general items such as onions, tomatoes, chilli, oil, rice, and dried fish. It is the kind of place local people usually send their children running to fetch something when they are in the middle of cooking the evening meal, and don’t have time to go all the way to the market to buy the missing ingredient.

loans.use: To buy more goods in bulk.

loans.name: Jamira

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 25 year-old Jamira H.. She is married and has one child, aged 3. In 2002, Jamira established her fish selling business. Working seven days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $170 every month from this business. Jamira requires a loan in order to buy more fish in bulk. She thanks you for your support.

SELFINA is engaged in economic empowerment of women in Tanzania through leasing and leaseback facility as a practical way to achieve the economic and social emancipation of women.

SELFINA has taken a lead role as a pioneer of micro-credit in Tanzania through Micro-Leasing. Customs and traditions in Tanzania normally make it difficult for women to own land and assets, thus they are termed not-creditworthy by financial institutions as they lack tangible collateral assets. This leads to poor financial support, hence poor access to basic needs and services for women with low incomes.

SELFINA buys and leases equipment to women. Where a client needs working capital, SELFINA buys equipment from said client, extending a loan to her, then leasing back the same equipment – a process called a sale and leaseback arrangement

loans.use: To buy more fish in bulk.

loans.name: Safia's Group

texts.en:
Safia baji, the wife of M.F., has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 20 years. She owns a two room brick house, and her husband has a motorbike rental business. She is applying for a loan for her husband, who wants to buy an additional motorbike.

She is joined in her loan group by three other members: Suraiya baji wants a loan to buy a sewing machine; Zubaida baji wishes to buy an auto-rickshaw (three-wheeled local vehicle); Allah Rakhi baji seeks a loan for her milk business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Sikujua

texts.en:
Mambo from Mbeya, Tanzania! This is 35 year-old Sikujua L.. She is married and has two children, aged 7 and 9. She has two dependents who live with her because they are orphans. In 2000, Sikujua established her used clothing business. Working six days a week, and nine to twelve hours a day, she earns about US $50 every month from this business. Sikujua has already received and successfully repaid three loans from SELFINA, and now requires a new loan in order to buy more used clothes. She thanks you for your support.

Second-hand clothes journey across the oceans from America and Europe, and are then washed, ironed and sold in bulk by wholesalers in Dar es Salaam to retailers who then re-wash and re-iron them for sale on the streets of Dar es Salaam and the surrounding towns and villages. These clothes are becoming increasingly popular, especially amongst the younger generation, because they are so cheap and because of the general appeal of anything western or modern. Many people argue that the popularity of the West’s cast-offs is damaging the local cloth and garment industry. There are many people who still appreciate the beauty of traditional Tanzanian dress; however, the growing market in used clothing and its importance to many micro-entrepreneurs cannot be denied.

loans.use: To buy more used clothes.

loans.name: Kalamera Group

texts.en:
Mariatu K. sells food items such as rice, peanut butter, salt, palm oil and magie. She is 35 years old and married with three children; her husband works as a driver and his salary could hardly meet the family's needs. Mariatu's business is the main source of income for the family. She has been running her business since 2003 on a very small scale; with her previous loan from SMT, she increased her stock and income.

The business group also includes: Mbalu K., owner of a local restaurant who would like to purchase more food items; Mohamed S., owner of a stall of general merchandise; Abi C., also an owner of a stall of food items in the market; and M. M., who sells onions, sugar, soap and more. Together they are applying for a group loan to improve their individual businesses.

loans.use: Purchase food items and other inventory.

loans.name: Razia's Group

texts.en:
Razia baji, the wife of G. F., has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 35 years. She owns a three-room mud house and is the mother of three sons. Her elder son is 22 years old and finished his education until the 5th standard (grade). Her next son is 12 years old and in the 5th standard, while her youngest son is 8 years old and in the 2nd standard. She is applying for a loan on behalf of her eldest son, a driver by profession who wants to buy and drive his own auto-rickshaw (three-wheeled vehicle).

She is joined in her loan group by three other members: Shakeela baji wants a loan to expand her electric shop; Irshad baji wishes to buy an auto-rickshaw; Farzana baji wants a loan to expand her food business.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Suraiya's Group

texts.en:
Suraiya baji, the widow of M.S., has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 35 years. She owns a two-room brick house and is the mother of four children, the oldest being her 25-year-old son, upon whose behalf she is applying for a loan. He is a fruit seller who wants to buy more fruit to expand his business.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Sajida baji and Kalsoom baji want a loan to expand their grocery shops; Zahooran baji wishes to buy a donkey cart, while Noorjahan baji wants to buy boxes (which are used to carry sweets).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Go Be-Foe 1 Group

texts.en:
Emma B. is 30 years old and married with three children. Emma would like to expand her business selling fish and diversify her market-outreach in the villages. She is glad to apply for a loan again from Kiva. She has said that Kiva is her source of life. She is happy that she is now using her own capital generated from a previous Kiva loan, whereas previously she had to purchase fish on credit at a high price.

Isatu B. sells fire wood and palm oil, and Salamatu L. owns a stall selling palm oil and rice. The three entrepreneurs have been working together as a group for more than a year and the members guarantee each other. Together they are requesting a loan to expand their individual businesses.

loans.use: Purchase more died fish, firewood, palm oil and rice.

loans.name: Manzooran's Group

texts.en:
Manzooran baji, the wife of M.S., has lived in Chichawatni, Pakistan for the last 25 years. She owns a two-room brick house and is the mother of three children: two sons and one daughter. Her elder son works with his father, who has a grocery shop. She is now applying for a loan to enable her husband to diversify his shop with a broader selection of food and drinks.

She is joined in her loan group by four other members: Rukaiya baji wants a loan to buy fruits and vegetables to sell; Akbari baji wishes to buy a cart for loading food materials; Hamidan baji wants to buy fruits to sell while Amina baji wants a loan to expand her electric shop.

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Nadia's Group

texts.en:
Nadia baji, the wife of S. I., lives in Chichawatni, Pakistan, where she is the mother of two daughters. Nazia baji’s husband is employed selling cooked chickpeas and rice on a cart. She is applying for a loan for her husband, who wants to start his own business selling the same food on a cart.

Nadia is joined in her loan group by four other members: I. baji and Kaniz baji each want a loan to buy a donkey cart; Nasreen baji wants to buy vegetables and fruits to sell, while Haleema baji wishes to buy an auto-rickshaw (three-wheeled vehicle).

This is a group loan. The loan funds will be distributed among the group members, each of whom will invest in her own business. The members guarantee one another's loans, so if one member does not repay, the other members are responsible.

loans.use: To expand their businesses.

loans.name: Tamaraneh Group

texts.en:
Issa K. is 40 years old and married with five children. He sells basic building materials such as wiremesh, nails, and a few bags of cement. With his previous loan, he diversified his business; now he would like to do this again to increase his income. His plan is to establish a large building materials shop.

Issa is the group leader for three other members. Henry C. owns a small pharmacy selling basic medicine; Fatmata K. sells rice, peanuts and palm oil; and John K. sells plastic sandals and cotton clothes. The group is requesting a loan to expand their individual businesses.

loans.use: Increase stock of building materials, medicines and food items.

loans.name: Tamaraneh Group

texts.en: K. I. is 40 years old and married with 5 children.  He sells basic building materials such as wiremesh, nails, and few bags of cement.  With his previous loan, he diversified his business and would like to do the same to increase his income.  His future plan is to establish a large building materials  shop.  I. is the group leader with 3 other members.  Henry owns a small pharmacy that sells basic medicines, Fatmat sells rice, peanuts and palm oil and John sells plastic sandals and cotton clothes.  The group is requesting a loan of Le. 3,200,000 to expand their businesses.

loans.use: Increase stocks of bulding meterials, medicines and food items.

loans.name: La Alianza, Group 4

texts.en:
Ysabel "Maritza" S. is in her fourth loan cycle with her Esperanza International Bank of Hope, La Alianza ("The Alliance"). She used her first loan to open her women's underwear store, "Interiores Peniña." Maritza tried to open her store before her loan, but the business failed because she was unable to keep the store stocked with the variety and selection her customers wanted. Now, just two years later, Interiores Peniña is always full of merchandise--and customers!

Before she joined her Bank of Hope, Maritza was dependent on her husband to send her money for necessities. As a result of her business's success, Maritza is now able to easily provide everything her family needs, from home furnishings to school supplies for her grandchildren.

Many budding entrepreneurs in this Quisqueya community have been inspired by the success of Interiores Peniña, and have joined Esperanza as a result. Maritza's home (which adjoins her shop) serves as the center for Bank of Hope collection meetings, and her loan officer, Damaris, often uses story to inspire her other borrowers.

loans.use: Interiores Peniña (women's underwear store)

loans.name: Good Luck Group

texts.en:
Yeabu Z. K. is the group leader. She owns a stall of general merchandise in the market of Magburaka in Sierra Leone. Yeabu is 50 years old and married with three children; she has been running her business for the last ten years on a very small scale. She would like to expand the business for one of her children to take over in the future, and also to increase her income to meet her children's school requirements.

Aminata S., Adama K. and Yeabu G. all sell various food items at the same market in Magburaka. Together, the four are requesting a group loan to expand their individual businesses.

loans.use: Purchase more rice, palm oil, onions, and sugar.

loans.name: Vasyl

texts.en:
Vasyl W. is married with a 5-year-old son. He lives in Ivano-Frankivsk, Western Ukraine. Vasyl used to work as a policeman, but he resigned and decided to launch his own venture. He is a truly committed and hard-working entrepreneur. Vasyl has successfully been operating a transportation service business for fifteen years. Presently, Vasyl’s daily income is about $40.

He has a perfect credit history and plans to expand his business to attract more customers. Vasyl is seeking a loan for 5,000 Grivnas to put toward a newer vehicle he has just purchased. He works hard to offer customer-friendly services in order to stay competitive in the market. With the additional funding, Vasyl hopes to continue to increase sales and improve living conditions for himself and his family.

loans.use: To purchase new vehicle for transportation service business

loans.name: Alla

texts.en:
Alla has been selling groceries and drinks in Novomoskovsk's central market for ten years. A true entrepreneur, she studies the market to determine client needs and preferences. Industrious and enterprising, Alla is focused on expanding her business. Presently, she has a monthly income of about $600.

Alla is currently seeking a loan for 1,500 Grivnas. She plans to use the loan to increase her assortment of fresh merchandise and expand her business. With the increased sales and profits, Alla hopes to open additional vending kiosks and improve the living standards of her family.

Note: this is a short term express loan that will be repaid in one month.

loans.use: To purchase fresh groceries to expand her food market business

loans.name: Vladimir

texts.en:
Vladimir owns a successful car repair business in Novomoskovsk, Central Ukraine. He has a small repair shop in a good, visible location where each day he works on vehicles fixing different problems. Vladimir is married and has 4 kids. His business provides an important source of income for him. He currently makes around $1000 in a typical month.

Vladimir has been in this business for 15 years. He has requested a short term express loan of 1000 Ukrainian Grivnas to add to his working business capital and help purchase new car parts. He hopes to increase his client base and profitability. Vladimir is hoping to expand his business and generate additional income to invest in his younger son’s medical treatment. The boy was paralyzed following a stroke and needs special treatment and expensive medication.

Note: this is a short term express loan that will be repaid in one month.

loans.use: To purchase new car parts and expand repair business

loans.name: Lidiya

texts.en:
Lidiya lives in Novomoskovsk, Central Ukraine. After high school she began working as a market vendor. However, Lidiya wanted to start her own business, so she opened a small kiosk selling women’s clothing in the central city market. She has now been in business for 5 years.

Lidiya has a perfect credit history with “Nadiya Ukraine” and has promptly repaid all loans that she has received from the organization. Lending services have allowed the consistent expansion of her small business. Currently, her monthly net profit amounts to $400. Lidiya is requesting a loan for 2500 Grivnas to increase her inventory of clothing. She believes that a good assortment of clothing items will attract many customers, increase her sales profits and help the success of her business. Lidiya is hoping to invest generated income into the further expansion of her business and eventually open a new vending facility.

loans.use: To increase and diversify clothing inventory to support greater sales

loans.name: Tehmenaneh Group

texts.en:
Yeabu T. is 41 years old and married with three children. She sells local agricultural products such as rice, palm oil and peanuts. She works hard go generate income for her children's school requirements. Married to a subsistance farmer, Yeabu invested part of her loan into food production and she is happy that the family had good harvest of rice, cassava and peanuts to last until next season. Her business and income also increased, and she would like to further diversify the business.

Yeabu is the leader for a business group that also includes Ya Marie S., who sells dishes; Ya Marie T., who sells used clothing; and Ismail K., who owns a stall of African-print cotton materials in the same town. The group is requesting a loan so each member can expand their business.

loans.use: Increase inventory of used clothes, African-print material, and local food produce.

loans.name: Mujeres En Desarollo: Group 1

texts.en: Eudocia R. Zapota, 23, is in her second loan cycle with Esperanza and is the president of her Bank of Hope, "Mujeres en Desarollo" ("developing women").  She takes the job seriously, making sure that her fellow associates pay attention to their loan officer, Felix, but she can also be seen laughing and joking during the collection meetings.  She lives with her large family of 3 brothers, 2 sisters, and one-year-old daughter, Denelis.  With her future loans, she hopes to one day acquire a bigger, more spacious shop for her salon, and to purchase her own home for her and Denelis.  Most importantly, she wishes to keep working at the job she loves so that her daughter "will never lack anything."

loans.use: Salon de Eudocia

loans.name: Honest Group

texts.en:
Marie is 40 years old and married, with 4 children. She sells palm oil, but at a very small scale. Marie would like purchase 80 gallons of palm oil to increase her inventory and income.

Marie T. is a the leader for a group that has been working together as a rotating savings club for the past three years. The group also includes Mariatu C., who sells plastic sandals; Kadiatu K., who owns a small restaurant selling local food; and Mabinty S., who also sells plastic sandals. The group would like to expand their businesses, and is therefore requesting a loan of Le.3200000 ($1,100 USD).

loans.use: Increase stock of palm oil, rice and plastic sandals.

loans.name: Silper

texts.en:
Silper is a 45 year old married mother of 8 childen, four of whom are in school. She lives with her family in Nyalenda Kisumu, Kenya. She is the proprietor of five businesses, all supported by KMET and Kiva partnerships. She has received and fully paid four microfinance loans from KMET. She is currently applying for US $800 to strengthen her cereals and retail shop businesses.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To strengthen her cereal and retail shop businesses.

loans.name: Milicent

texts.en:
Milicent is a 32 year old married mother of 4 children. She lives with her family in Nyalenda Kisumu, Kenya. She runs a retail shop where she sells fast-moving commodities such as sugar, milk, soap, kerosene, rice, and flour. She has received three microfinance loans from KMET/ Kiva and has repaid them all. She currently requestsUS $800 to buy more stock.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: Add more stock to her business.

loans.name: Beatrice

texts.en:
Beatrice is 27 years old. She is married and has 3 children, two of whom are in school. She lives with her family in the Dunga slums of Kisumu, Kenya. She is the proprietor of a fruit stall she started in 2005. She requests US $600 to purchase more stock of fruits in bulk.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of fruit.

loans.name: Lino

texts.es:
Mr. Lino lives in the Laureles Sur neighborhood, he is 43 years old, married, and his wife works as a domestic employee and supports her husband with the expenses of their home. They have three children ages 3, 5, and 7, and Mr. Lino hopes to provide for them a dignified home and to help them develop into contributing members of society.

Mr. Lino had a loan through AFODENIC before and it was with that that he acquired his current home. The loan that he is asking for now is to construct a wall for a room in his home. The new wall will allow him to have better security in his house.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva volunteer.

Don Lino habitan en el barrio Laureles Sur, tiene 43 años de edad, es casado, su esposa se desempeña como empleada doméstica, y apoya a su marido con los gastos del hogar. Tiene tres pequeños hijos de 3, 5 y 7 años edad, a los cuales Don Lino espera darles una vivienda digna y formarlos como personas útiles a la sociedad. Desde hace algun tiempo Don Lino accedió a préstamos a través de AFODENIC, y es con ello con los cuales el ha ido componiendo su casa. El préstamo que solicita ahora es para construir una pared de su casa de habitación. La actividad que desempeña Don Lino es de guarda se seguridad.

loans.use: Construction of a wall for his home.

loans.name: Ilva Del Carmen

texts.es:
Ilva is 30 years old and is a shopkeeper. In her home she has a small store where she sells basic products of consumption to people in her neighborhood Laureles Sur. She started this business 5 years ago with her own capital and it has continued to grow thanks to the loans of AFODENIC.

Ilva’s dream is to see the store converted into a prosperous business that will give her financial stability. Ilva is married and has 4 children of the ages of 4, 6, 8, and 12. With the loan she would make a concrete wall so as to make it stronger and more secure.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva volunteer.

Ilva tiene 30 años de edad, es una pequeña comerciante, en su casa de habitación tiene una pulpería donde ofrece productos de consumo básico para sus vecinos del barrio Laureles Sur. Hace 5 años empezó este negocio con capital propio y ha ido creciendo gracias a los préstamos otorgados por AFODENIC.

El sueño de Ilva es ver su pulpería convertida en un negocio próspero y autosostenible. Ilva es casada y tiene 4 hijos de 4, 6, 8 y 12 años de edad. Con el crédito hará un muro minifalda de concreto para así hacerla más fuerte y más segura.

loans.use: Construction of a wall in her home

loans.name: La Beneficencia Group

texts.en: Rosa L. Alisander has received two loans from her Esperanza International Bank of Hope, La Beneficencia. With them she has started a market, Colmado Alisander, which is frequented by many members of the community. The store is connected to her house and is the site of La Beneficencia's collection meetings. Rosa and her husband Dalaceo have 6 children, who take up all of Rosa's time outside of the store. Her dreams for the future include an education for her children and a larger store that sells a larger variety of things.

loans.use: Colmado

loans.name: Mary

texts.en:
Mary is a 45 year old mother of 3 school-aged children. She ventured into farming two years ago. She grows vegetables such as sukuma wiki (kales), onions, and tomatoes along the shores of Lake Victoria. She is able to supply the produce in high demand to her customers. She requests US $700 to purchase farm inputs.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase farm inputs

loans.name: Rosibel

texts.es:
Rosibel began her work in the field of education 16 years ago in private schools, Rosa Lanzas and San Francisco de Asis, which were not recognized by the ministry of Education, but later named in the NER Sn. Esteban de Juigalpa. For the past 11 years, Rosibel has left her house every day at 6:00 a.m. in order to walk 5km to her place of work at the school every day. Of her two children, the eldest, at the age of 17, is studying his 5th year of secondary school and her other child is currently studying in primary school. She is now pregnant with her third child due to be born in the month of July. During her 7 previous loans, she has demonstrated great responsibility and paid back on time. This credit will be used to change the roof of her house, which currently has a level plastic roof, so that it will not leak water. She is hoping for the loans, even though they are small but they have helped her a lot and also helped they people that work with her. AFODENIC is an organization that treats its clients with great care and respect, in addition, it is the first institution that has offered this support to the salaried sector.

Translated from Spanish by Laura Kirkvold, Kiva volunteer.

La profesora Rosibel inicia su labor educativa a los 16 años en escuela privadas, Rosa Lanzas y San Francisco de Asis 4 años que no fueron reconocida por el ministerio de Educación, posteriormente fue nombrada en el NER Sn. Esteban de Juigalpa, con 11 años de servicios sale de su casa todos los dias a las 6:00 a.m ya que camina 5 Km a pie para llegar a su escuela, ingresando a las 4: 00 p.m tiene 2 hijos el mayor de 17 años estudiando el 5 año de secundaria y el otro primaria, está embarazada esperando el mes de julio para el nacimiento de su tercer bebe, durante sus siete créditos ha demostrado responsabilidad y cumplimiento con sus pagos, este crédito lo utilizará para cambiar el techo de su vivienda sobre todo el de su dormitorio que tiene como cielo razo plástico para no mojarse, manifestó que los créditos aunque pequeños pero le han servido de mucho a ella y a otras personas que trabajan con ella. No piensa quedar mal pues AFODENIC es una financiera que trata con respeto y amabilidad a sus clientes y demas fue la primera institucion que brindó este apoyo al sector asalariado.

loans.use: Home improvements - change of roof

loans.name: Sarah

texts.en:
Sarah is a 24 year old mother of two children. She lives with her ifamily in the Dunga slums of Kisumu. Sarah, who runs a vegetable stall, requests US $600 to purchase more stock of vegetables.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase stock of vegetables

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a 22 year old married mother of 2 children. She has been the proprietor of a vegetable stall since 2007. She sells vegetables such as kale, tomatoes, rice, eggs, beans, fruits and onions. She has applied for US $600 to buy more stock of vegetables.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To purchase more stock of vegetables.

loans.name: Rose

texts.en:
Rose is a 60 year old mother of three living children. She also supports three orphans. She lives in the Nyalenda slums of Kisumu, Kenya. Rose, who is a trained community health worker, has been in second hand clothing business for many years. She has received three microfinance loans from KMET/KIVA partnership and has repaid them all. She currently requests US$800 to buy more second hand clothes in bulk.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To buy more stock in bulk.

loans.name: Florence

texts.en:
Florence is a twenty year old married mother of two children. She began her current business of dress making in 2006.She specializes in both women’s and men’s clothing. Florence plans to move to a more spacious site and buy tailoring materials with her loan of US $600.

Disclaimer: Due to recent events in Kenya, the security situation in many communities remains unsettled, affecting many local businesses. Lenders to this entrepreneur should be aware that this loan may represent a higher default risk, and should be willing to accept this additional risk in making their loan.

loans.use: To buy tailoring materials.

loans.name: Sebazungu

texts.en:
SEBAZUNGU G. is among the early clients of VFC. He was born in 1979 in Eastern Province, Bugesera District. He is married and stays with his family in Nyamata Sector/ Nyamata-city.

In 2005, G. started a small-scale business trading shoes. His business was conducted in a small house he was renting for three thousand per month (Rwf3,000). He was living in the same room with 4 orphans (2 boys and 2 girls) as a child-headed household family. After joining VFC, his business grew, and he started to inject the small loan he obtained to purchase other items. According to G., “I was wondering where to find money in order to increase my capital and inject in other businesses which overlap with the shoes I am selling. It is by that reason that I approached VFC and started with trousers since people who were buying shoes could also be in need of trousers.” This business was initiated in 2006 with 10 men's trousers. G. says, "The loan I am going to get from VFC is going to help me to increase my business and hence improve my family welfare."

loans.use: Increase his business and hence improve his family welfare

loans.name: Aydalina Del Socorro

texts.es:
Aydalina is 37 years old, with two children of 18 and 2 years of age, her life companion is a taxi driver and supports her in maintaining her family. She hopes to benefit from good health to raise her small two year old child, and continue the education of her other 18 year old child. She wants to educate them and support them in all they need.

For 4 years she has had a small general store in her home, which she set up with her own funds and whose plans are to make her business larger and convert into a general store. With the loan she will fortify the inventory to increase her sales and begin the desired growth.

Aydalina tiene 37 años de edad, tiene dos hijos de 18 y 2 años de edad, su compañero de vida es taxista y la apoya en la manutención de su familia. Espera poder gozar de buena salud para criar a su pequeño niño de 2 años, y seguirle dando estudios a su otro hijo de 18 años. Quiere educarlos y apoyarlos en todo lo que necesiten.

Tiene 4 años de tener una pequeña pulpería en su vivienda, la que montó con fondos propios y cuyos planes son poder hacer más grande su negocio y convertirla en miscelánea. Con el crédito fortalecerá el inventario para aumentar sus ventas y así empezar su crecimiento tan deseado.

Translated by Mark Holmes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Fortify inventory to increase sales

loans.name: Nzabahayo

texts.en:
VFC has a target of empowering community members’ capacities, in particular those who run income-generating activities and livestock and are in need of capital to push up their businesses. J. is among those who has benefited from the loan and today has seen improvement.

J. was born in 1971 in Southern Province in the former District of Musange. When he was 8 years old, he joined his maternal grandmother in Bugesera where he dwells with his wife, his three children, and two orphans without any familial relationship.

J. likes farming activities. He left traditional cattle keeping and is involved in modern farming techniques. He can afford to achieve his objectives with the strong support of VFC. With the first loan he got, J. bought a crossbreed cow worth Rwf 180,000. With his good harvest of beans, he managed to pay for the loan. He took the second loan raised to Rwf 100,000 and bought a hybrid calf. His target is to get three crossbreed cows. He expects to start milking the first cow within 7 months. The estimated milk quantity is 20 liters each time.

J. is now seeking another loan so that he can procure a grown-up hybrid cow in order to increase the milk production for Nyamata society and also generate income to meet the family's day-to-day needs.

J. said, “Milk does not only increase the household income, but is also is a nutritious product essential to reduce malnutrition. I hope the loan I am expecting to get from VFC will change the life of my family members as well as Nyamata community”. Credit is essential to this family.

loans.use: To buy additional heifer

loans.name: Barirwanda

texts.en:
B. is a man who was born in 1972 in Musenyi sector in Bugesera District. He is married and the father of two children and also in charge of one orphan.

B. was an agricultural laborer for a long time. It was in 2000 that he thought about running a small-scale business. In that year, Bugesera District (formerly Nyamata District) was characterized by drought caused by a prolonged dry season, which hampered the agricultural sector. B. thought to orient his efforts to something which can generate income and allow him to handle the basic household needs. He therefore dealt in selling a few items used by community members. He was selling soaps, sugar, box matches, soda (one crate) and salt. After noticing that the profit he was generating was too small because of lack of adequate capital, he decided to apply for his first loan from the VFC. His business was expanded and the shop became more attractive since people could not travel the long distance from Musenyi where his shop is to Nyamata for purchasing items. 

Business has positively impacted the family of B., who was homeless before joining VFC and today is living in his own house constructed in a trade center of Rumuna with the family. The same house has a room which B. uses as a shop where community members can get various food, clothes, shoes, and other necessary items needed by many households. From the business he can afford to pay wages for the agricultural laborers, and all family members have registered for medical insurance. 

B. is a good and trustworthy customer since he is among the VFC clients who pay back their loans at the stated period. Giving him a loan is empowering his business for the development of Musenyi society. He will use this loan to buy processed food wholesale.

loans.use: To buy processed food wholesale

loans.name: Aba

texts.en:
Aba T. sells fish, cassava, and plantain. She is married, but her husband's income from fishing is not sufficient for Aba and her five children. Demand for her goods is high, and she is looking to expand her business to increase her profits.

She is asking for additional capital to expand her business.

loans.use: Additional capital to expand her business

loans.name: Ana Lucia

texts.es:
Doña Ana Lucia is 42 years old, married and has one two year old daughter. Her husband is a teacher, and she works as a seamstress to support themselves. Four years ago her husband helped her buy a sewing machine to be able to do so.

She began this business because she saw a need to help her husband in building their home, where they would need more income to make some improvements. With the time that she has had the business she has gained a lot of experience and would like to continue improving to offer quality service to her clients. With the requested loan she will purchase rafters and zinc to repair the roof of their house so that winter does not affect their home.

Doña Ana Lucia tiene 42 años, es casada y tiene una niña de 2 años. Su esposo es docente, y ella para apoyarlos se dedica a la costura. Su esposo hace 4 años le ayudó en la compra de una máquina de coser para poder realizar esta actividad.

Ella empezó este negocio porque se vió en la necesidad de apoyar a su marido en la construcción de su vivienda, necesitaban más ingresos para poder hacer algunas mejoras. Con el tiempo que ha tenido el negocio ha adquirido mucha experiencia y desea seguir mejorando para ofrecer un servicio de calidad a sus clientes. Con el crédito solicitado comprará perlines y zinc para reparar el techo de su vivienda, para que el invierno no les afecte su vivienda.

Translated by Mark Holmes, Kiva Volunteer

loans.use: Purchase of rafters and zinc to repair roof

loans.name: Sorie's Group

texts.en: This group has 4 members: Sorie C., Lamin C., Alimany S. and Lamin B.. They all work for the Military. Because military salaries are small, they all engage in trading or development activities such as buying corrugated iron or bags of cement to complete building projects. They are requesting a loan of Le 4,000,000.00 to expand their trading business and invest in new materials. This loan will be divided equally between the four men and will be repaid from their monthly salaries.

loans.use: To buy corrugated iron zincs

loans.name: Francisca

texts.en:
